content.text: The student ensures that the metre ruler is horizontal
Briefly describe how to check that the ruler is horizontal. You may draw a diagram

The student adjusts distance \(d\) between the \(0.0 \text{cm}\) mark and the \(1.50 \text{N}\) load, as shown in Fig. 1.1. He moves the thread supporting the \(1.50 \text{N}\) load so that it is at the mark on the metre ruler shown in Fig. 1.2

parts.label: (ii)

content.text: The reading on force meter X is shown in Fig. 1.3
Record \(F_{\mathrm{X}}\), the reading on force meter X shown in Fig. 1.3

issues: LaTeX subscript (_) found outside math mode

content.text: The student moves the \(1.50 \text{N}\) load to distances \(d = 10.0 \text{cm}, 30.0 \text{cm}, 50.0 \text{cm}, 70.0 \text{cm}\) and \(90.0 \text{cm}\). For each distance \(d\), he reads the value \(F_{\mathrm{X}}\) on force meter X
His readings are shown in Table 1.1
Plot a graph of \(F_{\mathrm {X}}/\mathrm {N}\) (y-axis) against \(d/\mathrm {cm}\) (x-axis). Start the axes at the origin (0, 0)
Draw a best-fit straight line

The student pours hot water into the beaker and records the initial temperature \(\theta\) in Table 2.1. She then records the temperature \(\theta\) every 30 s. Her values are shown in Table 2.1
Describe **one** technique that you use to ensure that temperature readings in this type of experiment are as accurate as possible
Estimate what the temperature \(\theta_{300}\) is at 300 s. Use the readings from Table 2.1 to guide you
Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{1}\) during the first 90 s of the experiment. Use the readings from Table 2.1 and the equation:
where \(T = 90 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_{0}\) and \(\theta_{90}\) are the temperatures at \(t = 0\) and \(t = 90 \text{s}\)
Include the unit for the cooling rate
Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{2}\) during the middle 90 s of the experiment. Use the readings from Table 2.1 and the equation:
where \(T = 90 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_{90}\) and \(\theta_{180}\) are the temperatures at \(t = 90 \text{s}\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\)
Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{3}\) during the last 90 s of the experiment. Use the readings from Table 2.1 and the equation:
where \(T = 90 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_{180}\) and \(\theta_{270}\) are the temperatures at \(t = 180 \text{s}\) and \(t = 270 \text{s}\)
Use your results from (d) to describe the overall pattern of the rate of cooling of the water in the experiment. Justify your answer by reference to your results
Estimate the final temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{F}}\) of the water after several hours

Draw the circuit symbol for a variable resistor

A student investigates circuits containing different combinations of resistors
Circuit A is shown in Fig. 3.1. Circuit A is not complete
A student investigates the refraction of light
Refraction is the change in direction of a ray of light when passing into a transparent substance, as shown in Fig. 4.1
Plan an experiment which enables him to investigate how the concentration of a gel affects the angle at which light is refracted when passing from air into the gel
A transparent gel block can be made by dissolving gel powder in hot water in a mould and allowing it to cool. Changing the amount of powder will change the concentration
Concentration is measured in \(\text{g} /\text{cm}^3\)
The apparatus available includes:
• samples of gel made at different concentrations and labelled with those concentrations
• a ray-lamp which produces a narrow ray of light
In your plan:
• list any additional apparatus needed
• explain briefly how to do the experiment, including the measurements to take
• state the key variable to keep constant
• draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are not required to enter any readings in the table)
• explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion
